results.title: The Challenge
results.creator_credit: Wayne Le Clos, John Carter, Gil Brealey and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: This film deals with a situation in which one man is promoted over an another who has more experience in the same area. The man overlooked displays his resentment by insisting that nothing has changed and that he will continue to behave as he has always done. The question posed concerns the preservation of old relationships after promotion while making it clear that one is now boss. Suitable for upper secondary level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Wayne Le Clos, John Carter, Gil Brealey and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: The Celts
results.creator_credit: J Williams, Caryl Ebenezer, Opus Television and SBS-TV
results.brief_description: Six part series that discusses the history and legends of the Celtic people of Early Europe. Using paintings, historical locations, buildings and re-enactments, this very detailed and informative documentary provides a historical insight into the Celts and their culture and is complimented by some stunning landscape cinematography. Narrated by John Morgan.

results.title: A Dead song? [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: J Williams, Caryl Ebenezer, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, S4C International, Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales) and Opus Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “The Celts”.
The final episode in a six part series that discusses the history and legends of the Celtic people of Early Europe through to the year 2000. The Celts over the centuries have suffered many forms of identity crisis, be it religious, cultural, or lingual and this program explores, in particular, the near death of the Celtic languages during the 18th century through to the early 20th century. It would appear one of the major influencing factors behind the disappearing dialects occurred as each Celtic nation (Ireland, Scotland and Wales) came under English rule in the name of a United Kingdom. However, as history tells, these three nations certainly did not choose English rule voluntarily - it was forced upon them. The program discusses the various uprisings that took place including the Battle of Culloden (Scotland 1745), the Great Potato Famine (Ireland 1846) and the Easter Uprising (Ireland 1916). Also examines about the Industrial Revolution and its effect on the Welsh population where speaking Welsh was banned in schools and a concerted attempt was made by the ruling English to obliterate and decimate everything Welsh, including their culture and language. Today it is a different story as the Celts begin to reassert themselves as independent nations - Ireland in 1922, Scotland in 1998 and Wales heading there. Each nation has its own Celtic language television channel and through the means of mass media, the Celtic language and culture is being revived and perhaps redefined as the current generation explore their identity as a Celt but also as part of a global population. Using re-enactments, archival footage, stills and prints, this very detailed and informative documentary provides a historical insight into the Celts and their culture and is complimented by some stunning landscape cinematography. Narrated by John Morgan.
results.creator_credit_for_label: J Williams, Caryl Ebenezer, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, S4C International, Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales) and Opus Television

results.title: Legend and reality [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: J Williams, Caryl Ebenezer, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, S4C International, Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales) and Opus Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “The Celts”.
The fifth in a six part series that discusses the history and legends of the Celtic people of Early Europe through to the year 2000. Using paintings, historical locations, buildings and re-enactments, this episode spans the 8th century through to the 17th century, recounting the wars, invasions, and the blood spilt in the name of the Church and a “United Kingdom”. The story begins with the Viking invasion in 793 AD on the Holy Isle of Lindisfarne where the complex web of Celtic Churches were savagely attacked and destroyed. This invasion, occupation and settlement, continued on through the years to 1066 and the Battle of Hastings when William, Duke of Normandy, defeated Harold II, and took the English throne heralding the beginning of a mass takeover by the Normans. Over time, the Celtic culture was almost absorbed and reality and truth lost its way as in the legend of King Arthur - the myth lives on even today. The continual assault on the Celtic communities by the English led to turmoil and revolt during the 1300s, with Scotland seemingly the only one to retain its independence through the emergence of William Wallace and then Robert Bruce. By 1532 AD, Brittany was defeated and absorbed into France, and in 1536 Wales became part of England. Under the reign of Elizabeth I (1550-1600 AD), Ireland fell fully under English rule and so began the “Irish problem”. From 1608 onwards, “plantations” began in Ireland whereby Protestant English and Scottish were encouraged to settle in Ireland and try and rid Ireland of its Catholic population. This very detailed and informative documentary provides a historical insight into the Celts and their culture and is complimented by some stunning landscape cinematography. Narrated by John Morgan.
results.creator_credit_for_label: J Williams, Caryl Ebenezer, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, S4C International, Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales) and Opus Television

results.title: The Charm of Britain
results.creator_credit: Greg Grainger and Seven Network Limited (Australia)
results.brief_description: Britain in the 1990’s is in a period of transition. There’s division about the future of the Royal Family and doubts about the country’s closer links with Europe. Many in Scotland would like to become independent. The Welsh also want greater autonomy in running their own affairs. But through it all, the British remain British - and custodians of one of the most beautiful islands on earth. Less than a thousand kilometres long from top to bottom, and home to almost 60 million people, Great Britain may not be the world power it once was, but in terms of history and culture, it still has few equals. Our intention is to travel the length of this amazingly diverse country, observing the growing independence of many of its regions, sampling its rich traditions, as we discover for ourselves “The Charm of Britain”.

results.title: From Camelot to Christ [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: J Williams, Caryl Ebenezer, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, S4C International, Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales) and Opus Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Celts”.
The fourth in a six part series that discusses the history and legends of the Celtic people of Early Europe through to the year 2000. This program focuses on the Dark Ages, a time of the collapse of the Roman Empire in Britain and the impact this had on the future of the Celtic kingdoms is discussed. The removal of Roman authority in the north left the way open for fierce battles over dominant power in the Celtic kingdom. At this time the battle between the Saxons and the British began, with the ultimate success of the Saxons over the Celtic world despite the efforts of the Celtic heroes, rendered in Celtic folklore for the respite they brought for the British before the ultimate failure of their attempts to hold onto independence. One of the great figures to emerge from this time was Arthur, said to have halted the Saxon advance until the onset of the bubonic plague and the resulting disastrous effects on the British population which allowed the Saxons to conquer once again. At the same time the emergence of Christianity in Ireland is investigated in the program, with a discussion of the establishment of a veneer of the Roman Church over the already existing religious beliefs in the Celtic world and the eventual ruin of the true Celtic Church this caused.
results.creator_credit_for_label: J Williams, Caryl Ebenezer, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, S4C International, Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales) and Opus Television

results.title: The Chaplin review
results.creator_credit: Charles Chaplin and First National Pictures
results.brief_description: This video features two Chaplin favourites: Shoulder arms - Is an unusual mixture of realism and fantasy with Chaplin’s characteristic touches of slapstick, satire, irony and pathos. It has been suggested that Chaplin’s film provides a truer picture of World War I than most of the more ambitious dramas. The Pilgrim - Escaped convict Chaplin lands himself in all manner of situations when he disguises himself as a preacher. Silent films with English intertitles.

results.title: Sacred groves [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: J Williams, Caryl Ebenezer, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, S4C International, Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales) and Opus Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Celts”.
The third in a six part series that discusses the history and legends of the Celtic people of Early Europe through to the year 2000, this time with a focus on the Celts of Great Britain, Ireland and Wales and the ancient pagan religion of Druidism and its translation into the present day. The program discusses the fertility rights, rituals and burial rights that formed a large part of Celtic folk tradition and their mythology about the world after death with a focus on archaeological findings of riches and human remains in burial mounds as well as in peat bogs throughout Wales. The foundation of our present day Halloween in the ancient Celtic Feast of the Dead, where the earthly and supernatural world were said to intersect with nightmarish possibilities, is given as a striking example of a softened contemporary translation of ancient folklore. To this end a study is also made of the present day translation of Celtic religion, seen as a fairly removed version of the powerful Druidism of ancient times where, firmly routed in an engagement with nature, Druids were trained for twenty years to take their position in the highest priestly caste of the three orders and where great importance was placed on poetic Bards, sacrifice and no less than 200 gods and goddesses. The Druids’ fearful appearance to the Romans is also detailed, along with the stories of Druid rebellion against Roman invasion, let down in the end by lack of organisation against the most disciplined army of the world at that time and resulting in many elements of Druidism being banned or encapsulated in Catholicism.
results.creator_credit_for_label: J Williams, Caryl Ebenezer, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, S4C International, Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales) and Opus Television

results.title: Heroes in defeat [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: J Williams, Caryl Ebenezer, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, S4C International, Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales) and Opus Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Celts”.
The second in a six part series that discusses the history and legends of the Celtic people of Early Europe through to the year 2000. A study of rock art and archaeological findings of jewellery and various artefacts opens the program with a discussion of their symbolism that has remained relatively unknown for centuries save for their significance to key events and rituals inherent in the Celtic civilisation and their stylistic originality now known as ‘Celtic Art’. The program then traces the breakdown of Celtic society in the fifth century BC as a mass movement South of the Celtic population on the continent led to clashes with Rome and Delphi and a distribution of Celtic peoples to unexpected corners of the globe with a discussion of the great many theories that seek to explain this. The Celts in Britain are then examined in detail, with explanation of the ancient history associated with their presence there and the powerful farming, artistic and warrior traditions of their society. In tandem, the growth of the threat of the new Roman Empire to the Celts and the invasion of Celt’s new developing urban centres throughout the continent is detailed where despite the emergence of revolutionary leaders the strength of the Celts was no match for the discipline and well informed warfare techniques of the Roman soldiers. As the Roman Empire expanded its outreach Celtic Britain also came under attack but with a view to the next instalment in the series, it is said that they weren’t quite as successful in this endeavour as many believe.
results.creator_credit_for_label: J Williams, Caryl Ebenezer, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, S4C International, Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales) and Opus Television

results.title: In the beginning [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: J Williams, Caryl Ebenezer, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, S4C International, Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales) and Opus Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Celts”.
The first in a six part series that discusses the history and legends of the Celtic people of Early Europe through to the year 2000. This episode asks the questions as to what defines the Celts, both in myth and in genetics. The program opens with discussion of the origins of the Celts in central Europe, far from where they later settled, and examines their distinctive culture and rituals as evidenced in cave drawings, writings of other cultures and archaelogical findings. The tradition of sunworshipping, the movement westward as the weather changed and the gradual move to the iron age is discussed along with the changes in power structures, produce and cultural influences in the Celtic world as trade and thus riches increased. These elements are discussed with reference to archaelogical study while acknowledging the indefinate nature of the history of the Celtic people. The questions that arise as to how they got to Ireland, the area where the contemporary true Celts remain, are investigated with reference to conflicting theories about coastal migration patterns of the time or the ambiguous archaeological evidence which is featured in the area in order to illustrate some possibilities given the difficulty of tracing Celtic history. A study is also recorded in this program of the population in present day Celtic areas and their heritage through a genetic heritage testing project with local school children and a discussion of their family heritage. While the study is seen to shed an interesting light on tracing Celtic history through genetic means it also confirms and engages with the discussion in the rest of the program of the enigma that the Celts remain.
results.creator_credit_for_label: J Williams, Caryl Ebenezer, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, S4C International, Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales) and Opus Television
